newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Palestinians take first bite of U.S. fast food.
newsitem.headline: Palestinians take first bite of U.S. fast food.

text.p: Palestinians in the West Bank are getting their first taste of American fast food.
The Subway sandwich chain has opened its first branch in the Palestinian self-rule areas -- in Al-Bireh near Jerusalem.
"People like what we offer. We opened last Friday and we have had a good business since then," said Adnan Bahhour, a Palestinian American who returned to the West Bank in February.
Bahhour said he obtained the Palestinian franchise from the Connecticut-based chain after being turned down by McDonald's and Burger King, hamburger chains with branches in Israel.
He said McDonald's cited political instability as the reason for its rejection, despite more than three years of Palestinian peacemaking with Israel.
Bahhour has a franchise for all of the Palestinian areas but obtains supplies from the Israeli agent who also supplies a Jordanian franchise.
The West Bank and Gaza have undergone a social revolution since Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority took charge in parts of the areas under a self-rule deal with Israel in 1994.
While reluctant to invest in risky businesses that depend on goodwill from Israel for imports and exports, Palestinian expatriates have poured their money into the building and service sectors.
Many Palestinian restaurants already serve American-style fast foods such as burgers, chicken and pizzas alongside traditional dishes such as houmous and felafel.
Restaurants offering local and western specialities have opened across the West Bank and Gaza Strip to serve a growing business community and expatriates accustomed to eating out.
